definition: A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically one that is unwelcome.
Something that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected.
Showing a willingness to take surprisingly bold risks.
So lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring.
Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior.
Remove the moisture from (something); cause to become completely dry.
Lasting for a very short time.
Intensely enthusiastic or passionate, especially to an excessive degree.
Easily persuaded to believe something; credulous.
Of the same kind; alike.
(of a person, speech, or style of writing) using very few words.
(of an action, idea, or goal) deserving praise and commendation.
Tending to talk a great deal; talkative.
Make less severe, serious, or painful.
A person who is excessively concerned with minor details and rules or with displaying academic learning.
Dealing with things sensibly and realistically in a way that is based on practical rather than theoretical considerations.
The state or quality of conforming to conventionally accepted standards of behavior or morals.
Alternate or waver between different opinions or actions; be indecisive.
Liable to change rapidly and unpredictably, especially for the worse.
Great energy or enthusiasm in pursuit of a cause or an objective.
Fluent or persuasive in speaking or writing.
Open to more than one interpretation; ambiguous.
Expressed clearly; easy to understand.
Not able to be seen through; not transparent.
Spending money or resources freely and recklessly; wastefully extravagant.
Not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily.
(of a person) reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little.
Using or expressed in more words than are needed.
High-sounding but with little meaning; inflated.
(of an argument or case) clear, logical, and convincing.
Pompous or extravagant in language, style, or manner, especially in a way that is intended to impress.
Obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree.
(of language or style) concise and forcefully expressive.
(of speech or writing) using or containing too many words; tediously lengthy.
Showing great care and perseverance.
Conducive to success; favorable.
Gentle and kindly.
Having or showing care and conscientiousness in one's work or duties.
Having or showing great knowledge or learning.
Very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail.
Sparing or economical with regard to money or food.
(of a person) fond of company; sociable.
(of a person or action) innocent and unsuspecting.
Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
(of a person or organization) seeking to promote the welfare of others, especially by donating money to good causes.
Acting with or showing care and thought for the future.
(of a person or process) diligent, thorough, and extremely attentive to details.
Showing or feeling no interest, enthusiasm, or concern.
Hostile and aggressive.
Having or showing a willingness to act dishonestly in return for money or personal gain.
Contemptibly lacking in courage; cowardly.
Inclined to lay down principles as incontrovertibly true.
Deceive; trick.
Lasting for a very short time.
Use ambiguous language so as to conceal the truth or avoid committing oneself.
(of a phrase or idea) lacking significance through having been overused; unoriginal and trite.
A person who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions.
Unable to be placated.
Acting or done without forethought.
Lacking flavor.
Having or showing a wish to do evil to others.
A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.
Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action.
Characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; designed to impress or attract notice.
Lacking inspiration or excitement; dull.
(of an action or gesture) carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection.
Speak or act in an evasive way.
Tending to induce drowsiness or sleep.
Superficially plausible, but actually wrong.
Occurring at irregular intervals or only in a few places; scattered or isolated.
A long, angry speech of criticism or accusation.
A state of physical or mental inactivity; lethargy.
(of something perceived as hostile, threatening, or negative) become less intense or widespread.
Leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to avoid detection of or arrest for an unlawful action such as theft.
Restrain oneself from doing or enjoying something.
Render (something) poorer in quality by adding another substance, typically an inferior one.
Publicly recommend or support.
Increase the power
Make (suffering, deficiency, or a problem) less severe.
Combine or unite to form one organization or structure.
Make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better.
Consecrate (someone) with oil or an oily substance.
Pacify or placate (someone) by acceding to their demands.
Very old or old-fashioned.
Make (an unpleasant feeling) less intense.
Reduce the force, effect, or value of.
Make (something) greater by adding to it; increase.
State or assert to be the case.
Support or strengthen; prop up.
Begin to grow or increase rapidly; flourish.
The making of false and defamatory statements about someone in order to damage their reputation; slander.
Reprimand (someone) severely.
Sarcastic in a scathing and bitter way.
Express severe disapproval of (someone or something), typically in a formal statement.
The use of trickery to achieve a political, financial, or legal purpose.
Come together to form one mass or whole.
Cause surprise or confusion in (someone), especially by acting against their expectations.
(especially of an argument, story, or sentence) extremely complex and difficult to follow.
Confirm or give support to (a statement, theory, or finding).
Describe or portray (something) precisely.
Criticize unfairly; disparage.
Express contempt for; ridicule.
A forceful and bitter verbal attack against someone or something.
Persuade (someone) that an idea or belief is mistaken.
Conceal one's true motives
Insolent or impertinent behavior.
Make (something) more attractive by the addition of decorative details or features.
Cause (someone) to feel drained of energy or vitality; weaken.
Cause or give rise to (a feeling, situation, or condition).
Make (a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling) worse.
Show or declare that (someone) is not guilty of wrongdoing.
Praise enthusiastically.
Give a servile display of exaggerated flattery or affection, typically in order to gain favor or advantage.
Prevent or obstruct (an anticipated event or action) by taking action ahead of time.
Deny or contradict (a fact or statement).
Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
Provoke or annoy (someone) so as to stimulate some action or reaction.
A lengthy and aggressive speech.
Delay or prevent (someone or something) by obstructing them; hinder.
Just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary.
Accuse or blame.
Suggest or hint (something bad or reprehensible) in an indirect and unpleasant way.
Unwilling or refusing to change one's views or to agree about something.
Overwhelm (someone) with things or people to be dealt with.
Having or showing a tendency to be easily angered.
Give a lot of public attention and approval to (someone); treat as a celebrity.
Appease the anger or anxiety of (someone).
Render obscure, unclear, or unintelligible.
Harsh criticism or censure.
Exclude (someone) from a society or group.
Make (a disease or its symptoms) less severe or unpleasant without removing the cause.
Ward off (a weapon or attack) with a countermove.
Make (someone) less angry or hostile.
Prevent from happening; make impossible.
Increase rapidly in numbers; multiply.
Win or regain the favor of (a god, spirit, or person) by doing something that pleases them.
Complaining in a petulant or whining manner.
Argue or raise objections about a trivial matter.
Consign or dismiss to an inferior rank or position.
Refuse to accept or be associated with.
Provide evidence to support or prove the truth of.
Take the place of (a person or thing previously in authority or use); supplant.
Supersede and replace.
Regard with great respect; revere.
Make (someone) feel annoyed, frustrated, or worried, especially with trivial matters.
Speak or write about in an abusively disparaging manner.
Shake with a quivering motion.
